Ive been trying to figure out what short form of what I was trying to do back then would sound like because I thought I wanted to try something new on my revisiting of music, but hearing those old tracks make me want to try harder this time, and starting small. Im just thankful that I still have those tracks around to experience my journey even though back then I didn't feel  like the y were good enough for me to share because of the expectations I thought people had of me being the guy returning home after going to a great music school. q.a: it just sounds a little different. you'll have to try it and see. actually i can give you a really common example of where B/F# really is what you want. actually let's switch it to the key of C for easier explaining, and it's not actually Cmaj7/G, this example is C/G, but nonetheless i think you will be able to see the difference. Take the song 'happy birthday to you' in the key of C. right before the end of the song, on the last "birth". the harmony is probably playing C chord, but i think you'll find that the best place for the bass, at this point in the song, is G. i can name a trillion other examples of popular/classic/traditional songs, over the course of the last 300 years, that have had a 1(chord) over 5(bass) absolutely thrive in this right before the end finalistic 'the song's about to end' spot. you've heard it a million times. try putting C over C there instead .... it doesn't quite fit. it sounds like the beginning of the song, .... right before the end ? ... By the way, to complete the example just you you can hear it clearly, the 'good' way to do it, from the final line "birth" is C/G, "day" is D7, "to" is G7sus4, and "you" is C, preferably with the G note left out, just e c , with low C in the bass. and Fmin/Ab was on "hap"

q.a: these are 2 extremely different activities. it makes sense that you would feel lost trying to do a solo singer/songwriter 1 instrument+voc song as a full arrangement, and similarly it makes sense that it might feel impossible to take a full arrangement and perform it live with 1 inst+voc. they are completely different machines. the translation can  be made, but it might take a lot of experience to figure out how the heck it's gonna work. actually what i was explaining before is that they are such different things that i wouldn't recommend trying to get one to work like the other. you might just feel confused and frustrated. in other words, i would say don't try to play the same kind of guitar track. probably don't even use the guitar, or if you use guitar don't use the same one and don't play it in the same way, and definitely don't do that first. i was recommending doing the percussion first. that's just something i've learned from experience. not the drums, not the bass, not the chords, but actually the percussion. like shakers/tambs/hi hats, etc. ch-k-ch-k-ch that sort of thing. this is why you'll need to have your writing all zipped up at this point, tempo and roadmap need to be finalized in order for this approach to really work. if you're curious as to how to learn how to run such a complex operation, i would suggest starting with songs less than 5 seconds in length

q.a: it's going to be a very different activity, playing/singing as a 1 person live performer (guitar), vs. designing an arrangement. both processes can be very rewarding, but they're totally different. if you're doing an arrangement i would not recommend starting with your normal solo guitar performance. if you're working alone, i would strongly recommend using a click and doing percussion first. then do temp instruments, then temp vocal, then go back and re-build the instrumental arrangement, then finally re-do the vocal, then maybe touch up the instruments then maybe touch up the vocal. where as, on the other hand, if you'd rather capture the solo singer-songwriter/guitar performance, i would suggest capturing as much room noise as you can

q.a: when it comes to using a mouse to click on a button, it is extremely inefficient to maneuver the mouse to the location of a fake button and pretend to press it. however, that's a great thing to do when first learning the application. but as you approach an expert level, it becomes vitally important to add the extra speed of using the keyboard. this is only for button-style functions ('do a thing', etc). this does not apply to actual graphical functions that require motion/movement
q.q: Anyway so I looked it up and found out about the principle of keyboard comp atibilit y, which is similarly that all software should be accessible via keyboard because many people aren't able to use a mouse due to a disability. Not sure whether you knew that, but either way, it's a good opinion to be promoting and I'm glad I'm now a slightly less ignorant amateur web dev.

q.a: that generally looks pretty good to me, but the first thing that is definitely wrong is the "47"s, those should be 4maj7. besides that, to just nitpick the notation and not the actual content, when you say "5add6" i'd say it should be 56. (actually when doing it all in numbers like this i prefer to write the 6 higher than the 5, but that's not always so easy in text, especially plaintext like this, so i don't blame you). another thing, when you have the 1aug, i think it's most likely 1aug7. they're not doing us a favor with the release/cutoff of these chords being so long, the chords are bleeding into each other. Makes that flat5 thing much less effective than it could be, and difficult to identify because if we try to pause and isolate that moment by brute force, it's going to have the previous chord smeared in with it. But for sure plain as day to me that feels like a thing i always use, which would be a 3aug triad over b5 bass note. (not b5dim as you called it) so in this key, Baug/C#. if you listen carefully you can very clearly hear the E note (from the C/D chord)   change to Eb during the chord. also, for more even smaller nitpicks, the 2min on the second line is 2min7. just noticed the first chord at the very top also has a 2 in it. so you might say 1sus2,4. and the 1maj9 on the first line i would definitely call that 5/1 (5 over 1). straight off the yacht

q.a: i would say the intro is Bmin, setting up to seem like it's going to be in D, (hanging on the final A7 sounds like we're about to go to verse in D) but surprise, it's just not. verse is in A. this coasts along comfortably and normally in A, for a while. Then, when it goes "help me if you can i'm feeling down" this is essentually 2 parallel universes running side by side. according to what came before, this sounds like the 2 min chord. so the G will now sound like an interesting flat7. but by the time we hit the E7, all of a sudden you can re-map the entire last 4 bars (two chords worth) as if they have been in Bmin (D) the whole time. similarly showing up at that A7 hang about to put you to bed in D, which again it does not, it just stays in A. just does. to have the fun of going around and doing it all again

q.q:
I've had a YouTube channel since 2007 that I infrequently upload videos to and ever since 2011 I've been saying "okay - I'm going to get my shit together and make all these videos I have ideas for and get on a consistent release schedule." Every time I get my shit together, there's some major problem - like with an instrument, camera, software, or some other piece of gear.

Lately, I've had the time and money to get shit together and ACTUALLY DO IT but I tell myself "oh, I can't speak in front of a camera until I can get over this bad episode of acne" or "I need to have this or that to make for an interesting shot". I've realized that my problems are partially in my head and I've been making excuses, procrastinating, etc... I know this is partially due to my anxiety problems - and I've heard friends (mostly actors) describe it as "being in your head".

I say all that to tell you tha t your videos and audio recordings buried on your website that show a glimpse into your creative process - especially when you were starting with Vine - have really helped me and inspired me. A lot of that stuff made me feel like I wasn't alone and crazy whenever I talk to myself about grand ideas in order to sort things out or I try to hype myself up to get some creative endeavor done.

Is there any advice you can impart that'll encourage me to do "the damn thing"? Or could you explain how you came to figure out your "process" and how to quit procrastinating and making excuses?

q.a: even if you don't have absolute pitch, you can get away with it. all you have to do is flick a note, and you'll immediately know what key everything is in. the other players may also do the same, and/or if the keyboard player finds the key they can tell the other players. if all the players know the song, then that's great. if they don't, they can fake it using intuition and try to guess where it's going to go, and/or make ambiguous decisions until they get it. also what is quite common, if the keyboardist knows the song better than the others, they might say numbers or give number symbols with one hand. you may never believe this, but i think all the skills necessary to do this are actually skills that are not particularly common among people with true absolute pitch. absolute pitch may help you find 1 note if you're in handcuffs, but in terms of finding the chords and the rest of the song, it comes down to musicianship/music, which is quite unrelated to absolute pitch

q.a: my standard advice for this is to try doing projects of a smaller size. if you are still having the same symptoms, just try even smaller projects. keep reducing the project size until completion is easily and handily within sight. i think you will find a lot of newfound excitement in actually completing something for once! and you will actually learn a lot very quickly. it's like when you first walk into a new house, you walk through the entire house once. even if you don't do anything in each room yet, just walk through each room. Now you know how big the house is! and you generally know how it goes! very powerful information, will pave the way for bigger ideas in subsequent episodes
